com.stormpath.sdk.api

Interface ApiRequestAuthenticator

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    OAuthApiRequestAuthenticator
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    DefaultApiRequestAuthenticator, DefaultOAuthApiRequestAuthenticator

    public interface ApiRequestAuthenticator
    Authenticates an API HTTP Request and returns a result.
    Since:
    1.0.RC
    See Also:
    Application.authenticateAccount(AuthenticationRequest), authenticate(HttpRequest)

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      ApiAuthenticationResult authenticate(HttpRequest httpRequest)
      Authenticates an HTTP request submitted to your application's API, returning a result that reflects the successfully authenticated Account that made the request and the ApiKey used to authenticate the request.

    • Method Detail

      • authenticate

        ApiAuthenticationResult authenticate(HttpRequest httpRequest)
        Authenticates an HTTP request submitted to your application's API, returning a result that reflects the successfully authenticated Account that made the request and the ApiKey used to authenticate the request. Throws a ResourceException if the request cannot be authenticated.

        This method will automatically authenticate both HTTP Basic and OAuth 2 requests. However, if you require more specific or customized OAuth request processing, use the #authenticate(com.stormpath.sdk.http.HttpRequest) method instead. That method allows you to customize how an OAuth request is processed. For example, you will likely want to call OAuthApiRequestAuthenticator.authenticate(com.stormpath.sdk.http.HttpRequest) for requests directed to your application's specific OAuth 2 token and authorization urls (often referenced as /oauth2/token and /oauth2/authorize in OAuth 2 documentation).

        Example

        If your application does not run in a Servlet environment - for example, maybe you use a custom HTTP framework, or Netty, or Play!, you can use the HttpRequestBuilder to represent your framework-specific HTTP request object into a format the Stormpath SDK understands. For example:

         //assume a request to, say, https://api.mycompany.com/foo:

 public void onApiRequest(MyFrameworkHttpRequest request) {

    Application application = client.getResource(myApplicationRestUrl, Application.class);

    // Convert the framework-specific HTTP Request into a format the Stormpath SDK understands:
    HttpRequest request = HttpRequests.method(frameworkSpecificRequest.getMethod())
        .headers(frameworkSpecificRequest.getHeaders())
        .queryParameters(frameworkSpecificRequest.getQueryParameters())
        .build();

    ApiAuthenticationResult result = Applications.apiRequestAuthenticator(application).authenticate(request);

    Account account = result.getAccount();

    // Check to see that account is allowed to make this request or not before processing
    // the request.  For example, by checking the account's groups or any of your own
    // application-specific permissions that might exist in the group's or account's customData.
    assertAuthorized(account); //implement the 'assertAuthorized' method yourself.

    //process request here
 }
        Parameters:
        httpRequest - a manually-constructed HttpRequest instance An argument of a different type will throw an IllegalArgumentException.
        Returns:
        an ApiAuthenticationResult that represents the result of the authentication attempt.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the method argument is null or is not a HttpRequest instance.
        ResourceException - if unable to authenticate the request
        Since:
        1.0.RC4.6
        See Also:
        OAuthApiRequestAuthenticator.authenticate(com.stormpath.sdk.http.HttpRequest)
